text: Hi, we have bought the CMS and want to connect the primary domain -> Is this possible during build phase or we have to do this when the website is finished?
(So all url’s match <http://www.domain.com|www.domain.com> instead of <http://blog.domain.com|blog.domain.com>)
you'll need to use a temp domain until you're ready to launch
can i change the temp domain to the main domain for all the content when i’m done?
yeah
/poll “Just throwing this out there… A jQueryless HubSpot option” “:thumbsup_all: ” “:thumbsdown:”

I think it’s inevitable that it will happen one day but will not likely be soon.

There are also some cons to not using jquery - custom modules relying on it will not work on sites without it. Module makers will start to include jquery in their module, and multiple versions of jquery would likely load on a page due to modules calling different versions
so it has to be approached with caution and a good amount of planning and honestly the shift probably needs to be done on a slow moving basis. Moving incremental pieces off jquery first.
the solution to that would be to include the option for popular js frameworks so all dev's would use the same one. codepen does this to some extent
Mainly an option or toggle switch to turn it off for now is what I was thinking.

For those who need a little influence to say yes. Here you go
<https://medium.com/@trombino.marco/you-might-not-need-jquery-a-2018-performance-case-study-aa6531d0b0c3>

yes, but codepen also doesn’t have a problem HubSpot does.

Codepen can always suggest the latest version.

If HubSpot did that it’d open a can of worms. Because what about older modules?

he doesn’t seem to talk about backward compatibility and compiling to ES5 and whatnot.

that’s the main reason aside from “it’s what we’re used to” that jQuery is still chuggin’ along
what if they just forced everyone to write vanilla js? hehe
technically everything is vanilla js, because everything is just a library ontop of vanilla js abstracting things out
Thanks i’ll do that!
you don’t have to compile to ES5 if it’s already vanilla, no?
If you don’t care about backward compatibility and :internet-exploder:  you don’t have to. But if you do have to then babel is kind of a must

Quick “Dumb” question, but I can’t seem to find the right answer, I have an existing site on the HS CMS, I want to make a change to the design. Changes I make in the design tools (To a custom module) don’t seem to show on the website when I refresh. Is there something I have to do to re-publish with the new changes?
maybe a hard reload?
ok caching then :smile:
at least i had this happened to me a couple of times...
Use the HubSpot dev extention in the chrome extention store
<https://github.com/TheWebTech/HubSpot-Developer-Extension/wiki/So-you're-having-HubSpot-Caching-Issues%3F>
or just add a `?kjsdhfkjshd` to the end of the url
<#CBBAW6Z3R|community-browser-extension>
:smile: this is great, thanks
then nothing to worry about
lol well it the only way they would make it so we couldn’t use the libraries - and we still could it’d just make it hard, is to remove the require_js functionality and the linked assets
which just wouldn’t be a good move at all
here's an idea, integrate npm
I think vanilla js `!=` es6; therefore, no need for babel
npm with es6 imports would be cool

vanilla js considered all versions of javascript. Babel just makes it so you can write in the newer versions while still supporting older browsers.

<https://babeljs.io/>

If you had to manually write everything in es5 and lower it’d make manual js super tedious, and you’d have to polyfill everything yourself for the features you need
then the version numbers can be decided by HubSpot

I like to use `?asfsdg34vb`
could set it in the template head?

Heya <@UDFTHC6PK>, mind sending me more details in a DM? I'm not able to reproduce this right now, so I'd like to take a closer look.
can do
Is there any reason a user wouldnt be able to edit their email address under the profile & preferences section?
I thought i remembered hearing that HS is releasing multi step forms (maybe at partner day in May) and there was a beta. I am imagining this or does this exist somewhere?
lol and then add one letter to it each time
command + L, command + right arrow, a, enter
fastest way to do this, imo
save #123 `<http://www.example.com?ssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssss|www.example.com?ssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssss>`

I know the general tone with the :sprocket: product team the last 6-8 months is "How can we give developers *options* to decide what/how they want to build."

I don't know if there will ever be an  option to turn off/on jQuery completely - I believe we need  some level of code involved to make HubSpot work properly. But it's an interesting idea and I could see why that might be interesting.
make sure to add it to <http://ideas.HubSpot.com|ideas.HubSpot.com> and <#C26E7JT8V|ideas> :slightly_smiling_face:
:point_up_2:
In theory that should work. I've done that before - set all the open graph details in the template.

I don't know if that gets overridden on the page-level if someone add a featured  image to the page.
:point_up_2:
Would be a good experiment to try.
cc <@U8ZE2AMJ4>

Check out "HubToolKit" on <https://designers.HubSpot.com/open-source>

cc. <@UGCPXTKMW>
It's possible that it's restricted to only admins to protect against security concerns.

I have support looking at it and they said the user had the right permissions, I directed her to try incognito (support mentioned it) if they still have issues ill let you know
